awd_titl_txt: EPSRC-CBET: Molecular Engineering of Inhibitors to Self-Assembly:  Fundamental structure informing in silico design
awd_abstract_narration:
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are organic compounds composed of multiple aromatic rings.  PAHs are abundant in nature, and better understanding of their association in mixtures of organic solvents is important for a diverse range of engineering applications, including the fabrication of organic photovoltaics and the prevention of fouling in the petroleum industry. Even though PAHs are widely used in industry, little is known about how they associate with themselves or with other organic molecules. The proposed collaborative research between the US-based principal investigator and a UK team will use experiments and molecular simulations to study the aggregation of PAHs and identify the best ways to control self-assembly of PAHs in organic solvents. 

Promoting or inhibiting PAH association is accomplished by varying solvents or additives using heuristics or trial and error approaches. The proposed research aims to determine the role of heteroatomic functional groups (N, O, and S containing) on the self-association of PAHs and the solvated structure of PAHs. To accomplish this task, convergent bottom-up and top-down approaches will be pursued. In the bottom-up approach the intermolecular structure of simple solvent systems will be measured using neutron diffraction and molecular refinement. The experimentally consistent intermolecular structures obtained will be used to inform molecular simulations. In the top-down approach, the complexity of crude oil will be exploited to perform a large-scale investigation of the molecular features correlated with self-association. The collaborative research team combines expertise in neutron and X-ray scattering, atomistic and coarse grain simulation, and self-association measurements of hydrocarbons. The team has access to top of the line scattering facilities. The education and outreach plan aims to expose undergraduate and K-12 students to computer simulations and the role of chemical structure on molecular behaviors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are present in many commodity and consumer materials. Polyaromatic hydrocarbons are also semiconducting, making them a potentially transformative option for inexpensive solution-processing of advanced devices. One major barrier to the design of next generation organic electronic materials is the difficulty in predicting how solvents will interact with a diversity of PAHs, ones that may contain different atomic functional groups. Solvent selection will assist in controlling the association of PAHs in liquid mixtures, which is a critical design parameter to control electronic and mechanical properties. However, computer models of these compounds and solvent mixtures fail to accurately represent their local properties, impacting the coherent design of critical energy-related processes. Two specific examples include preventing the association of a class of PAHs called asphaltenes to reduce fouling in oil production pipelines and refineries; and promoting the association of semiconducting PAHs to facilitate electrical conductivity in organic electronic devices like low-cost solar cells. In this study, experimental and simulation tools were used together to shed valuable insight into the properties of PAHs on the molecular level and to improve our theoretical understanding of how to predict and control PAH association. This project was a collaborative effort, and funding was provided from the National Science Foundation (NSF) and the United Kingdom’s Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC). As such, the research was conducted with collaborators from the ISIS Neutron and Muon Source and Imperial College London in the UK. 

The project consisted of two convergent strategies to understand PAH liquid properties: a bottom-up and a top-down approach. In the bottom-up approach, neutron scattering experiments were used to measure the local structure in liquid PAHs, and the results were analyzed using molecular models. The goals were to assess the validity of existing models, understand the structures observed in these systems, and work towards improving molecular predictions. In the top-down approach, samples of complex PAHs from petroleum (i.e., asphaltenes) were characterized for their self-association and analyzed with advanced mass spectrometry techniques. The mass spectrometry results quantified tens of thousands of molecules to investigate whether specific molecular properties were found to enhance self-association. In essence, the top-down approach aimed to use the complexity of petroleum to reverse-engineer the molecular features that promote PAH association by analyzing a sample that contained more diversity than could be synthesized and studied individually. 

The bottom-up approach investigated the liquid phase structure of several PAHs varying from 2-4 ring structures (1-methylnaphthalene, phenanthrene, and pyrene) using a combination of neutron total scattering and analysis using atomistic simulation methods. It was apparent from the results that existing simulation approaches fail to accurately capture the extent of planar stacking among the molecules, with some vastly underpredicting and others over predicting how much the PAH sheets stack. For the compound 1-methylnaphthlene we found that certain orientations (parallel stacking) increased in structure as the temperature increased, an observation that challenges traditional assumptions about entropy. Further analysis demonstrated that changes in the liquid structure with temperature increases is related to the organization of molecules that maximize the free volume. Essentially, molecular orientations that pack the most efficiently will be promoted, which frees up more volume for the remaining molecules to move more freely and preserves the behavior where entropy increases with temperature. This finding provides a convenient tool, free volume estimates, to determine what conditions and molecular shapes would enhance PAH stacking. 

The top-down approach fractionated a petroleum sample as a function of the PAH solubility, which had been previously shown to correlate to the degree of PAH association. These samples were analyzed with high-resolution mass spectrometry where 20-30k unique molecular compounds were identified for each sample. The trends in the molecular composition compared to other measurements of PAH association did not show an obvious trend for simple molecular features that promote PAH association. An alternative explanation is that the association of PAHs in complex mixtures may be a balance of energetic forces (i.e., functional groups) and geometric considerations of molecular packing and organization (i.e., entropic effects). Thus, the technical conclusions of the top-down and bottom-up approaches unite with a similar conclusion that the association of PAHs requires an accurate understanding of both energetic and entropic forces. 

The support from the NSF enabled the training and dissertation of one PhD student, two peer reviewed research articles, seven research presentations, and the generation of new data using 16 days of neutron and 24 hours of X-ray scattering experiments at national research centers. In addition, through collaboration with the EPSRC in the UK, 5 additional publications have been produced through the joint projects. Further, manuscripts are in preparation for three additional peer reviewed articles as a result of the research award. In summary, we anticipate a total of ten publications to result from the research award, with seven already in print.
